Fig. 1 FTIR spectra of Mn-Na4 %, Na4 %-Mn, Mn/Na4 %, Mn-Na5 %, Na5 %-Mn, Mn/Na5 %, Mn-Na6 %, Na6 %-Mn, and Mn/Na6 %. (Fig. S32). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 PXRD patterns of Mn-Na4 %, Na4 %-Mn, Mn/Na4 % (a), Mn-Na5 %, Na5 %-Mn, Mn/Na5 % (b) and Mn-Na6 %, Na6 %-Mn, Mn/Na6 % (c) (Fig. S33). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for 2 %Mn-4 %Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts (Mn-Na4 %, Na4 %-Mn, Mn/Na4 %). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 SEM pictures of 2 %Mn–4 %Na2WO4/SiO2 (Mn-Na4 %, Na4 %-Mn, Mn/Na4 %) catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 EDX analysis of the IWI catalysts, showing the counts as a function of the excitation energy: the whole analysis spectrum (a) Mn-Na4 % catalyst, (b) Na4 %-Mn catalyst, (c) Mn/Na4 % catalyst. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 X-ray photoelectron diffraction spectroscopy has been performed to determine the elements forming the catalyst's surface. The sharp peaks observed in the above images of sample C correspond to the peaks of C1s, O1s, Na1s, Mn2p, Si2p, and W4d, which are proof of the presence of carbon, oxygen, sodium, manganese, silicon, and tungsten respectively in the atomic percentage of 3.01 %, 59.17 %, 0.63 %, 0.31 % and 0.41 % in the synthesized structure. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 H2-TPR profile of the fresh Mn-Na4 %, Na4 %-Mn, Mn/Na4 % catalysts. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 The effect of the preparation method on the catalytic performance of the 2 %Mn-4 %Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts (Mn-Na4 %, Na4 %-Mn, Mn/Na4 %) in the OCM reaction. Reaction conditions: CH4: O2 = 2, 4, 6: 1. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 The effect of the preparation method on the catalytic performance of the 2 %Mn-5 %Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts (Mn-Na5 %, Na5 %-Mn, Mn/Na5 %) in the OCM reaction. Reaction conditions: CH4: O2 = 2, 4, 6: 1. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 The effect of the preparation method on the catalytic performance of the 2 %Mn-6 %Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts (Mn-Na6 %, Na6 %-Mn, Mn/Na6 %) in the OCM reaction. Reaction conditions: CH4: O2 = 2, 4, 6: 1. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 The catalytic OCM mechanism proposed by Li et al. suggests that Na-coordinated WO4 serves as the active site for methyl generation, while nearby Mn2O3 facilitates gas phase activation. This mechanism, along with its modified versions, has gained widespread acceptance and discussion in the literature [3]. Science, Ferdowsi University of Mashhad Mashhad Iran Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Ferdowsi University of Mashhad, Mashhad, Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. This study presents various preparation methods for synthesizing a 2 %Mn-4 %Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst for the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) using an incipient-wetness impregnation procedure in one/two steps. The catalyst preparation involved modifying various additions and investigating the combination of 4 %, 5 %, and 6 % Na2WO4. Specifically, the effects of operating temperature and the methane-to-oxygen ratio on the catalyst's performance were investigated. The results suggest that the 2 %Mn-4 %Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst can operate efficiently under a low methane-to-oxygen feed ratio, making it suitable for OCM reactors. In our packed-bed quartz glass reactor, the dry-impregnated catalyst exhibited excellent performance, with a C2 selectivity of 37.20 %, ethylene selectivity of 13.94 %, ethane subselectivity of 23.26 %, and C2 yield of 28.22 %. Graphical Abstract Keywords Preparation method Heterogeneous catalyst Oxidative coupling Methane C2 selectivity Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The structure and preparation methods of catalysts have a profound impact on their catalytic performance, a subject that has been extensively explored in the literature [1–7]. Among the various catalysts studied, Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 has emerged as one of the most effective for the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) [2,8,9]. This catalyst, typically synthesized using methods such as initial moisture saturation [10–12] and solution combustion [1], exhibits varying properties and performance depending on the preparation approach [1,2]. The diversity of synthesis methods utilized in preparing Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts is well-documented, offering insight into how specific techniques influence catalyst characteristics ( Table 1). This variation underscores the importance of selecting an appropriate synthesis method to tailor catalyst design for enhanced performance. Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 is a composite catalyst comprising manganese (Mn), sodium tungstate (Na2WO4) [13], and silicon dioxide (SiO2) as a support material [14,15]. The synergy between these components is known to facilitate methane activation and promote ethylene formation [16]. The role of alkaline promoters, particularly sodium [17], has been emphasized in previous studies for its significant enhancement of methane conversion rates on the catalyst surface [8,18–23]. Additionally, sodium's ability to induce phase transitions in silica, from amorphous to cristobalite, plays a crucial role in modifying the catalyst's activity and selectivity [24–26]. The performance of the OCM process, in which methane and oxygen [27] are catalyzed to produce ethylene valuable compound in the petrochemical industry [3,28–31] is heavily influenced by reaction conditions such as temperature, pressure, gas composition, and space velocity. Optimal conditions must be determined through experimental testing to maximize ethylene and ethane production while minimizing by-products [32–38]. The OCM process encompasses both heterogeneous and homogeneous reactions, involving catalytic and non-catalytic mechanisms, respectively [39–43]. Significant research efforts, such as those by Keller et al. [44] and Hinsen et al. [45], have focused on improving catalytic activity, understanding reaction mechanisms, and optimizing the OCM process [1,19,44,46–50]. Despite these advances, achieving the desired efficiency and selectivity for industrial applications remains a challenge [44,51–54]. A critical step in the OCM process is the activation of methane molecules, facilitated by the catalyst through surface reactions that generate methyl radicals. These radicals are then released into the gas phase, where they undergo further reactions to form ethane and ethylene [55–61]. However, maintaining high yield and selectivity for ethylene, along with ensuring the catalyst's long-term stability on an industrial scale, remains a significant hurdle. Ongoing research continues to explore new catalyst formulations, synthesis methods, and reaction conditions to enhance OCM catalyst performance [4,54,62,63]. In this work, an incipient-wetness impregnation procedure was developed for preparing a Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst. This method was compared with other variations of the incipient-wetness impregnation procedure and different compositions of Na2WO4 in the preparation of Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts. The incipient-wetness impregnation procedure is gaining attention as a promising approach for synthesizing catalysts with novel functions and properties. This method was also extended to prepare Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts. The project's objective was to achieve a catalyst that exhibits high methane conversion rates, high selectivity, and, a high yield of the desired reaction product in the oxidative coupling reaction of methane. Fixed-bed quartz glass reactors were utilized to evaluate the performance and selectivity of the prepared catalyst. The effects of various operating parameters, such as temperature and the methane-oxygen ratio, were comprehensively investigated. In addition to the catalytic performance evaluation, the catalyst's structure was analyzed using infrared spectrum analysis (FT-IR), X-ray diffraction (PXRD), determination of specific surface area using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Temperature Programmed Reduction (TPR). These analyses provided valuable information about the synthesized samples' composition, crystal structure, surface area, morphology, elemental composition, catalytic properties, and insights into the catalyst's structural properties and surface characteristics. Overall, the aim was to optimize the catalyst's activity and selectivity by developing a incipient-wetness impregnation procedure and thoroughly investigating the operating parameters in the reaction. The structural analysis and reactor experiments were conducted to assess the catalyst's performance and potential for industrial application. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The catalysts were prepared following an incipient-wetness impregnation procedure [52,62]. The synthesis process involved using Mn precursor and Na2WO4 to prepare a set of nine catalysts with varying Na2WO4 weight loadings in three categories: I) A set of three 2 %Mn-X%Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts with Mn first-addition (Mn-NaX%): 2 %Mn-4 %Na2WO4/SiO2, 2 %Mn-5 %Na2WO4/SiO2, 2 %Mn-6 %Na2WO4/SiO2 Amorphous SiO2 (Silica Gel 60, 230–400 mesh grain size 0.040–0.063 mm) was impregnated with an aqueous solution of Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (99 % Merk Germany) and then desiccated at 130 ºC for 12 h. The dry catalyst precursor was then impregnated with an aqueous solution of Na2WO4·2H2O (99 % Merk) and dried at 130 ºC for 12 h. The final step was the calcination at 800 ºC for 8 h with a heating rate of 6 ºC.min−1. II) A set of three 2 %Mn-X%Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts with Na2WO4 first-addition (NaX%-Mn): 2 %Mn-4 %Na2WO4/SiO2, 2 %Mn-5 %Na2WO4/SiO2, 2 %Mn-6 %Na2WO4/SiO2 Amorphous SiO2 (Silica Gel 60, 230–400 mesh grain size 0.040–0.063 mm) was impregnated with an aqueous solution of Na2WO4·2H2O (99 % Merk Germany) and then desiccated at 130 ºC for 12 h. The dry catalyst precursor was then impregnated with an aqueous solution of Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (99 % Merk) and dried at 130 ºC for 12 h. The final step was calcination at 800 ºC for 8 h with a heating rate of 6 ºC.min−1. III) A set of three 2 %Mn-X%Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts with Mn/Na2WO4 simultaneous-addition (Mn/NaX%): 2 %Mn-4 %Na2WO4/SiO2, 2 %Mn-5 %Na2WO4/SiO2, 2 %Mn-6 %Na2WO4/SiO2 Amorphous SiO2 (Silica Gel 60, 230–400 mesh grain size 0.040–0.063 mm) was impregnated with an aqueous solution of Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (99 % Merk Germany) and an aqueous solution of Na2WO4·2H2O (99 % Merk), simultaneously and desiccated at 130 ºC for 12 h. The final step was calcination at 800 ºC for 8 h with a heating rate of 6 ºC.min−1. For more detailed information on the catalyst preparation procedure, refer to the Supporting Information (Table S1). 2.2 Experimental reaction testing The OCM experiments were conducted using a fixed-bed quartz reactor (outer diameter 2 cm, inner diameter 1 cm, length 50 cm). The reactor temperature was controlled using a temperature indicator and controller (TIC) coupled with a K-type thermocouple positioned within the reactor bed. Gas feeds of CH4, O2, and N2 (each with a purity of 99.999 %) were precisely regulated using mass flow controllers (Brooks, model 5850E) equipped with monitoring and control features. A cold trap was employed at the reactor outlet to capture condensed water vapor from the reaction products. For catalyst activity assessments, 0.3 g of catalyst (40–60 mesh) was packed with quartz wool to ensure isothermal conditions within the catalytic bed. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst underwent pretreatment under a nitrogen (N2) flow at 100 mL/min, ramping the temperature from 700 °C to 850 °C at a rate of 7 °C/min, followed by a 60-minute hold at the reaction temperature. Subsequently, OCM tests were conducted at temperatures ranging from 800 °C to 850 °C, maintaining a CH4/O2 molar ratio of 4, a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 12000 h−1, and atmospheric pressure. Each stage of the OCM process was maintained for 1 hour to ensure system stability. The reactant and product streams were continuously analyzed using a gas chromatograph (GC Varian 3400) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). CH4 conversion and C2 selectivity were determined based on GC data and carbon balance calculations: C H 4 Conversion % = n CH 4 i − n C H 4 0 n C H 4 0 × 100 Cx Selectivity ( % ) = ϰ n CxHy 0 n CH 4 i − n C H 4 0 × 100 Indices i and o denote the components at the reactor inlet and outlet, respectively. The variable n represents the number of moles of each component, and x represents the number of carbon atoms in each hydrocarbon CxHy. Yield of products was calculated as selectivity multiplied by methane conversion: C 2 Yield ( % ) = CH 4 Conversion ( % ) × C 2 Selectivity ( % ) 100 2.3 Catalyst characterization This study employed Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy to analyze the samples. The IR spectra were recorded using a Thermo Nicolet AVATAR 370 FT-IR instrument from the USA. The scanning range was set from 4000 to 400 cm−1, covering a wide range of infrared frequencies for comprehensive spectral analysis. The catalyst's X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were acquired using a GNR Explorer diffractometer (Italy, GNR company). Cu Kα radiation with a wavelength of λ = 1.5406 Å was employed within the 2Ɵ range of 10–80º. The XRD measurements were conducted at room temperature, with a tube current of 30 mA, tube voltage of 40 kV, and a detector type. A step size of 0.01 Å and an integration time of 3 were utilized during the experiments. The catalyst's BET surface area, pore volume (Vpore), and average pore size were determined using by Brunauer-Emmett- Teller (BET) and the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) approaches used by the Micromeritics TriStar-II instrument using nitrogen physical absorption at 77 K. Before surface characterization, the powders were degassed under vacuum at 150 °C for 4 hours. The BET surface area of the catalysts was measured using a Belsorp mini II volumetric absorption analyzer. The microstructure and morphology of the catalysts were analyzed using a scanning electron microscope (SEM) with the model LMUTESCAN BRNO-Mira3. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was conducted on the catalysts using an XPS SPECS UHV analysis spectrometer. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) analysis was conducted using a Chemisorption Analyzer, NanoSORD. A typical TPR analysis dried a 10 mg sample under a continuous flow of Ar at 300 °C for 60 minutes and cooled to 24 °C. The Ar supply was then halted, and a 5 % H2/Ar gas mixture was introduced at a 10 mL/min rate. The sample was gradually heated to 900 °C with a ramp rate of 10 °C/min and held at this temperature for 30 mins. The consumption of H2 was monitored using a thermal conductivity detector. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts 3.1.1 FT-IR The Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy results provide crucial insights into the structural composition and chemical interactions within the 2 %Mn-4 %Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst. Understanding these characteristics is essential for elucidating the mechanisms that govern the catalyst's performance in the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM). The FTIR spectra revealed key bands that are indicative of specific phases within the catalyst. Notably, a peak at 620 cm−1 was identified, corresponding to the presence of α-cristobalite, a crystalline form of SiO2 [55,76–78]. This finding is significant because α-cristobalite is known to form at elevated temperatures, particularly in the presence of sodium (Na) atoms during calcination. The conversion of amorphous SiO2 to α-cristobalite at approximately 800 °C suggests that the catalyst has undergone a structural transformation that enhances its thermal stability. This crystalline phase provides a rigid and stable support structure, which is critical for maintaining the dispersion of active species such as Mn and Na2WO4 [23,79], thereby potentially improving the catalyst's durability and performance under the high-temperature conditions required for OCM. The FTIR analysis also detected a prominent band at 3434 cm−1, attributed to the stretching vibrations of hydroxyl (O-H) groups. These hydroxyl groups are particularly important in the context of the OCM reaction mechanism. Methane activation, the initial and rate-limiting step in OCM, involves the abstraction of hydrogen atoms from methane molecules to form methyl radicals. The presence of hydroxyl groups on the catalyst surface facilitates this process by interacting with active oxygen species, enhancing the generation of methyl radicals. Additional key bands were observed at 475 cm−1 and 815 cm−1, corresponding to the Mn-O-Si and W-O-Si vibrational modes, respectively [8,23,26]. These bands confirm the successful incorporation of tungsten and manganese oxides into the SiO2 matrix, forming robust metal-oxygen-silicon bonds. The formation of these bonds is significant for several reasons. First, the Mn-O-Si bond suggests that manganese species, which are known to enhance the oxygen mobility within the catalyst. Increased oxygen mobility is vital for maintaining an active lattice oxygen pool that facilitates the selective oxidation of methane [80]. Second, the W-O-Si bond indicates the presence of tungstate is effectively anchored to the silica support, providing active sites that are crucial for methane activation. The presence of peaks at 1108 cm−1 and 951 cm−1, associated with Si-O stretching and Si-O-Si bending vibrations, respectively, confirms the structural integrity of the silica framework [25,78]. As a result, the FTIR characterization of the 2 %Mn-4 %Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst reveals a well-defined structure with distinct crystalline phases, functional groups, and metal-oxygen-silicon interactions. The presence of α-cristobalite enhances the catalyst's thermal stability, while the hydroxyl groups and metal-oxygen bonds play crucial roles in the methane activation process and overall catalytic activity. These findings provide a clear understanding of the catalyst's structural and chemical properties, which are directly linked to its high performance in the oxidative coupling of methane [25,33,40,78,81]. Fig. 1. 3.1.2 XRD To investigate the varying activity of catalysts with different percentages and additions of Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2, X-ray diffraction analysis was conducted, and the active Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts were compared. The XRD analysis revealed the presence of several main crystalline phases in the catalysts, namely Mn2O3, Na2WO4, and α-cristobalite. The XRD patterns of Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts are depicted in Fig. 2a-c respectively. The XRD spectra of the Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts demonstrated distinct crystalline phases, notably the α-cristobalite crystalline phase, which exhibited characteristic peaks at 2θ angles of 22.1°, 28.5°, 31.5°, 36.1°, 42.9°, 44.9°, 46.9°, 47.1°, 48.8°, 54.3°, 57.1°, and 62.0° (ICDD No. 00–001–0438). Additionally, the XRD patterns revealed the presence of Na2WO4, as evidenced by peaks at 2θ angles of 16.9°, 27.6°, 32.5°, 48.8°, 52.1°, and 57.1° (ICDD No. 01–074–2369)], along with Mn2O3, represented by peaks at 2θ angles of 33.1°, 38.1°, and 44.8° (ICDD No.00–002–0896) [75,82,83]. Table S3 (a-c) comprehensively compares the different phases observed in the synthesized catalysts and references previous reports. This comparative analysis helps establish connections between the identified phases and their potential contributions to the catalytic activity. The analysis revealed the presence of Na-O-Si interaction between Na2WO4 and SiO2 in all the catalysts [72]. amorphous silica plays a role in determining the catalytic performance of Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts in the OCM process. Additionally, various studies have identified cristobalite as the main phase in the catalysts. The amorphous silica support crystallizes into α-cristobalite upon calcination at 800 °C. The diffusion of Na ions in the SiO2 substrate promotes this phase transformation at lower temperatures than pure SiO2 [45,75]. The α-Cristobalite, in particular, has been reported to facilitate the dispersion and chemical bonding of the active sites with the support material [9]. Baoting Huang et al. [84] conducted a PXRD analysis and observed a clear dependence of the crystal phases of Mn2O3 and Na2WO4 on the concentrations of the respective precursors used [84]. Regarding the Na and W systems, the saturation order plays a significant role in the material's crystallinity [9,84]. The peak profiles of all samples exhibited similar characteristics, featuring notable peaks at approximately ∼32.5°,∼38.1°,∼44.9°, ∼48.8°, and ∼52.1°, corresponding to the Miller indices of (222), (400), (332), (431), and (440), respectively. These peaks are indicative of a cubic Mn2O3 crystal system, as previously assigned (JCPDS file no: 97–000–9091) [85]. The XRD pattern illustrates the characteristic peaks of sodium tungstate (Na2WO4·2H2O). Notably, some of the powder's peaks align with the principal peaks observed in the prepared catalysts. Specifically, peaks corresponding to the (111), (220), and (311) orientations are evident at 16.9°, 27.6°, and 33.1°, respectively, consistent with the cubic structure of Na2WO4. This alignment is supported by the Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS) 12–772 and/or 53–678 database entries [9,40,84,86,87]. Quantitative analysis from Table S3 in the Supporting Information reveals notable differences in phase shifts. Specifically, during the deposition of the Mn first-addition onto the silica substrate, a significant increase in the 2θ value is observed, resulting in a right shift between the planes in the Mn2O3 phase. Conversely, upon deposition of the Na2WO4 first-addition onto the silica substrate, a lower shift in 2θ is observed, indicating a left shift between the planes. In the hybrid state involving Mn, Na, and W, both right and left shifts between the planes were observed. Similarly, when comparing the Na2WO4 phase, both right and left shifts were observed. Therefore, it can be inferred that the method of metal deposition on the silica surface significantly influences the shift between the Mn2O3 planes. 3.1.3 BET The catalysts exhibited surface areas ranging from 29 to 43 m²/g. The Mn4 %-Na silica catalyst had the lowest surface area of 29.45 m²/g, while the Na4 %-Mn silica catalyst had the highest surface area of 43.88 m²/g. The Mn/Na4 % silica catalyst had a surface area of 33.69 m²/g. The OCM process begins by activating methane molecules on the catalyst surface, followed by their coupling through oxidation and subsequent release of reaction products. A catalyst with a lower surface area reduces the number of active sites, which helps prevent overcrowding and promotes the diffusion of methane and oxygen molecules to the catalytic sites [88,89]. This decrease in surface area also limits exposure to carbonaceous species, thus reducing catalyst deactivation and extending its lifespan. The surface area of the Mn-Na4 % catalyst is lower compared to the Na4 %-Mn and Mn/Na4 % catalysts. Similarly, the average pore diameter and total pore volume of the Mn-Na4 % catalyst are also lower than those of the Na4 %-Mn and Mn/Na4 % catalysts. As shown in Table, the catalyst doped with Na2WO4 initially exhibits the highest surface area, average pore diameter, and total pore volume compared to the Mn-Na4 % and Mn/Na4 % catalysts. Based on the diagrams, the type H3 hysteresis loop observed at the surface adsorption-repulsion temperature suggests a relationship with catalysts possessing a layered structure characterized by time-dependent pore formation. The results are summarized in Table 2 and Fig. 3. For detailed information on catalysts, please refer to the supporting information, which includes the BET isotherm plots of all catalysts (Figures S1–S5) in the Supplementary Information. 3.1.4 SEM The SEM images revealed distinct surface structures among the three catalysts ( Fig. 4). This discrepancy can be attributed to the presence of different compositions. Specifically, the Mn/Na4 % catalyst exhibits a fixed, predetermined structure, while the Mn-Na4 % and Na4 %-Mn catalysts display varying structures. The addition of Mn, Na, and W onto the catalyst's surface in varying states and sequences over SiO2 significantly altered its SiO2 morphology. When Na was introduced as the second layer in the Mn-Na4 % catalyst, it led to the accumulation of SiO2 particles, forming elongated rods on the catalyst surface, with a corresponding surface area of 29.45 m2·g−1. Conversely, when manganese was added as the second layer onto SiO2, the underlying network structure was maintained with fewer rod-like structures, yielding a surface area of 43.88 m2·g−1. Moreover, the simultaneous addition of Mn and Na2WO4 onto the SiO2 surface resulted in an intermediate morphology between the first and second states, characterized by shorter and more uniform rods. It exhibited a surface area of 33.69 m2·g−1. This observation highlights that introducing sodium to the catalyst surface as the secondary layer reduces the catalyst's surface area and triggers the transformation of amorphous SiO2 into cristobalite, which exhibits more excellent selectivity compared to the Na4 %-Mn catalyst. Consistent with the previous findings of Wang et al.'s group, sodium appears to play a crucial role in facilitating phase transitions. Conversely, when manganese is incorporated as the secondary layer, the surface area experiences an increase, while the simultaneous addition of manganese, sodium, and tungsten results in a surface area intermediate between the preceding two states. Notably, in this catalyst formulation, methane conversion and selectivity were observed to be higher than those achieved with the Mn-Na4 % and Na4 %-Mn catalysts. The results demonstrate that the catalytic activity in the OCM is enhanced when MnxOy species are dispersed on the silica substrate in conjunction with the concurrent presence of Na2WO4 particles, implicating both of these species as integral components of the active center. This finding aligns well with the redox mechanism proposed by Jiang et al., which posits that methane activation occurs at the Na2WO4 site while oxygen activation occurs at the Mn2O3 site. Subsequently, electron transfer between these sites facilitates the regeneration of the active center, thereby completing the catalytic cycle (Figure S35) [70]. EDX analysis assessed the homogeneity of cation distribution within the catalyst structures (Table S4). The objective was to determine if Na, Mn, and W cations were uniformly dispersed throughout the catalysts. This analysis is crucial because the formation of hotspots with concentrated populations of metal cations near the surface, resulting from inhomogeneous cation dispersion, can adversely affect the selectivity of OCM reactions. During the pre-experimental phase, multiple samples of various catalysts were analyzed, leading to the realization that hematite should be avoided. This is crucial in achieving a catalyst structure with uniformly dispersed cations and minimizing the localized intensity of active sites. The results of this analysis, focusing on the distribution of affinity cations, are presented in Fig. 4 (Figures S6-S16). The individual component spectra obtained from the EDX analysis are presented in Fig. 5. These spectra provide insights into the presence of Na, Mn, and W atoms in the as-prepared catalyst. The EDX analysis confirms that the cations were uniformly distributed throughout the catalyst structure, validating their homogeneous dispersion [90]. The atomic ratios of Mn/W in all three catalysts were determined through calculations. Specifically, the ratios were found to be 3.11, 0.6, and 8.26 for the respective Mn-Na4 %, Na4 %-Mn, and Mn/Na4 % catalysts. These ratios provide insight into the composition and potential catalytic behavior of each catalyst in the OCM reaction. 3.1.5 XPS The binding energy values obtained from XPS analysis indicate specific oxidation states for different elements [91,92]. The Mn2p spectrum shows a characteristic binding energy of 642 ± 0.1 eV, corresponding to the Mn3+ oxidation state on the catalyst surface ( Fig. 6). The Na1s peak observed in Figure at 1073 ± 0.1 eV indicates the presence of Na+ state. The W4f spectrum in Figure exhibits a binding energy of 35.6 ± 0.1 eV, which is expected for the W6+ state. The C1s spectrum in Figure shows a peak at 285 ± 0.1 eV, representing the C1s state. Similarly, the O1s spectrum in Figure displays a peak at 535 ± 0.1 eV, corresponding to the O1s state. The Si2p spectrum in Figure exhibits a peak at 105 ± 0.1 eV, indicating the Si2p state. It is worth noting that distinguishing between the WO3 and Na2WO4 phases based on XPS analysis alone is challenging since they exhibit the same W6+ state [93–95]. Table 3 presents the observed binding energy and elemental concentration near the surface of the Mn/Na4 % catalyst, as determined by XPS characterization. Stoichiometric calculations revealed that the 2 %Mn-4 %Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst had an average atomic composition of 0.63 % Na, 0.32 % Mn, 36.62 % Si, 59.1 % O, and 3.02 % C. The high-resolution spectra of Mn2p, Na1s, and W4f for the fresh catalysts are depicted in Fig. 6 (Figure S17). These spectra provide detailed information about the chemical states and bonding configurations of the respective elements on the catalyst surface [96–101]. 3.1.6 H2-TPR The reducibility of the catalyst and the interaction between the active and supported catalysts were investigated using the H2-TPR technique, as shown in Fig. 7, the H2-TPR profiles of the freshly calcined supported 2 %Mn-4 %Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts, Mn-Na4 %, Na4 %-Mn, and Mn/Na4 %, with peaks observed at approximately 729 °C, 737 °C, and 726 °C, respectively. Comparatively, the reduction peak temperature of the Na4 %-Mn catalyst increases compared to the Mn-Na4 % catalyst, while the average number of network O atoms decreases. The freshly calcined Mn/Na4 % catalyst exhibits a reduction peak at around 726 °C, indicating a slight decrease in reactivity compared to the other two catalysts. The reduction behavior of Mn-Na4 %, Na4 %-Mn, and Mn/Na4 % catalysts exhibited similarities. The temperature range of 450–550°C is commonly associated with the reduction of Mn species, while the range of 650–850°C is linked to the reduction of W species. The decrease in the reduction temperature of W species can be ascribed to several factors: (i) a weakening of the interaction between W species and the support, (ii) an augmentation in the dispersion of tungsten oxide species, and (iii) the prevalence of octahedral coordination over tetrahedral coordination for the species involved [93,102]. Moreover, variations in the method of H2 consumption are influenced by the preparation technique employed for the Mn-Na-W/SiO2 catalyst. This discrepancy serves as evidence for the existence of distinct metal-containing species or differing modes of interaction among metal components and the support in samples prepared through disparate methods. These findings suggest significant changes in the redox properties of these metal species, possibly due to a strong interaction between the WO4 2- component and the SiO2 crystals [47]. Ji et al. emphasized the critical importance of the α-cristobalite phase for the formation of C2+ catalysts with Na2WO4 and SiO2. They highlighted that the interaction between the α-cristobalite structure and the WO4 2- tetrahedral structure played a vital role in C2+ production, with the active surface species residing in the phase between these two components. Elkins et al. further emphasized the significance of the interaction between the α-cristobalite structure and the WO4 2- tetrahedral structure in C2+ production. They also noted that the WO4 2- tetrahedron stabilized the Mn2O3 and Na2WO4 phases, ensuring the catalysts maintained their high activity during the reaction. Additionally, Palermo et al. [103]. suggested that sodium (Na) played a dual role in promoting the activity of MnOx-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts, acting as both a chemical and structural promoter [102,104,105]. These findings collectively indicate that the presence of the α-cristobalite structure, Na2WO4 crystals, and the crystalline structure in the Mn/Na4 % catalyst significantly enhance catalytic activity (Figure S34). 3.2 Catalyst performance test The catalytic performance of 2 %Mn-4 %Na2 WO4 /SiO2, 2 %Mn-5 %Na2WO4 /SiO2, and 2 %Mn-6 %Na2 WO4 /SiO2 catalysts in the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) reaction highlights the significant impact of both the sequence of catalyst preparation and the concentration of sodium tungstate (Na2 WO4). These factors critically influence the balance between methane conversion, product selectivity, and C2 hydrocarbon yield. In the first catalyst, 2 %Mn-4 %Na2 WO4 /SiO2, it was observed that the sequence of Mn addition prior to Na2 WO4 (Mn-Na4 %) resulted in the highest methane conversion rates, reaching up to 81.35 % at 850°C, with a commendable balance of selectivity towards C2 hydrocarbons. This configuration showed that lower temperatures favored the formation of C2 hydrocarbons, particularly ethylene, while higher temperatures and methane-to-oxygen ratios increased CO and CO2 production, suggesting a shift towards complete oxidation. In contrast, when Na2 WO4 was added first (Na4 %-Mn), the catalyst exhibited slightly lower methane conversion and a higher tendency towards complete oxidation, as indicated by increased CO and CO2 selectivity, thus reducing C2 hydrocarbon yields. This highlights the importance of the sequence in determining the distribution of active sites and surface properties. Furthermore, the simultaneous addition of Mn and Na2 WO4 (Mn/Na4 %) generally resulted in higher C2 selectivity at lower temperatures, but as the temperature increased, the selectivity shifted unfavorably towards CO and CO2, with a corresponding decrease in the ethylene/ethane ratio. As the Na2 WO4 concentration was increased to 5 % in the 2 %Mn-5 %Na2 WO4 /SiO2 catalyst, the trends observed were consistent with those at 4 %, but with more pronounced effects. The Mn-Na5 % configuration maintained a high methane conversion with a notable increase in CO selectivity, particularly at higher temperatures, which suggests that increasing the Na2 WO4 concentration amplifies the complete oxidation pathway. The Na5 %-Mn sequence led to lower methane conversion and even higher CO2 selectivity, further reducing the C2 hydrocarbon yield and shifting the product distribution away from ethylene. When the Na2 WO4 concentration was further increased to 6 % in the 2 %Mn-6 %Na2 WO4 /SiO2 catalyst, the trend continued, with a further decrease in methane conversion and a marked increase in CO and CO2 selectivity, indicating a dominant complete oxidation pathway. The Mn-Na6 % configuration provided the best performance within this higher concentration range, balancing methane conversion and C2 hydrocarbon selectivity, albeit less effectively than at lower Na2 WO4 concentrations. The focus then shifts to determining the optimal synthetic method, which is thoroughly discussed and analyzed in Tables S23-S28. These tables examine the outcomes when Mn is added first (Tables S23 and S24), Na is added first (Tables S25 and S26), and a mixture of both salts is added simultaneously ( Figs. 8–10) (Figures S18-S31) (Tables S27 and S28). 3.2.1 Examining the effect of the addition method on catalyst selectivity In the presence of 4 % Na2WO4, the highest selectivity is achieved with the simultaneous addition of manganese salt and sodium tungstate. The second-highest selectivity in this composition is observed when manganese salt is added first, followed by the third-highest selectivity when sodium tungstate is added first. Examining the combination with 5 % Na2WO4, the highest selectivity is observed with the initial addition of sodium, followed by the simultaneous addition of manganese and sodium (Mn/Na), and the third-highest selectivity is associated with the initial addition of manganese. For the composition with 6 % Na2WO4, the highest selectivity is achieved in the Mn/Na state, followed by the first Na state in the second rank, and the third rank is associated with the first Mn state. 3.2.2 Examining the effect of the addition method on reaction efficiency In the context of 4 % Na2WO4, the highest efficiency is achieved with the Mn/Na state, involving simultaneous additions of the first Mn and the first Na. Moving to the 5 % Na2WO4 composition, the highest efficiency occurs with the initial addition of sodium, followed by the first Mn state and then the simultaneous Mn/Na state. This suggests that for optimal yield, the simultaneous Mn/Na synthesis method may not be preferable. However, if selectivity is a priority, the Mn/Na synthesis method remains a suitable choice. In the case of 6 % Na2WO4, the Mn/Na state demonstrates superior efficiency, followed by the first Na state and, lastly, the first Mn state. Remarkably, the comparative assessment of efficiency and selectivity remains consistent in the 6 % Na2WO4 combination. Specifically, the increasing percentage of Na exhibits a positive influence on both efficiency and selectivity (reference). 3.2.3 Examining the effect of the addition method on the ethylene-to-ethane ratio In the 4 % Na2WO4 combination, the ethylene content significantly decreases in the Mn/Na state. The optimal configuration is observed in the first Mn mode, followed by the first Na state and then the Mn/Na state. Moving to the 5 % Na2WO4 composition, the Mn/Na state yields the highest ethylene-to-ethane ratio, followed by the first Mn state and then the first Na state. Similarly, in the 6 % Na2WO4 composition, mirroring the 5 % composition, the Mn/Na state proves favorable, followed by the first Na state and then the first Mn state. In the case of the Mn/Na synthesis method at a 6 % Na2WO4 composition, optimal conditions are achieved, showcasing maximum selectivity, efficiency, and the best ethylene-to-ethane ratio notably, at a temperature of 850 °C, a methane-to-oxygen input feed ratio of 2 results in the highest selectivity, efficiency, and ethylene ratio. However, it's crucial to highlight that under other conditions, specifically with an input feed ratio of 4, the Mn/Na synthesis method at 6 % Na2WO4 still maintains favorable outcomes. Therefore, for the design and operation of an ethylene production reaction in a reactor, it is advantageous to employ the Mn/Na synthesis method at a 6 % Na2WO4 composition, maintaining a temperature of 850 °C and adopting an input feed ratio of 4. When exploring the Mn/Na synthesis mode, it is observed that a methane-to-oxygen input feed ratio of 2 proves to be more effective for achieving optimal selectivity and high efficiency. On the other hand, if the focus is on maximizing methane conversion percentage and obtaining a higher ethylene-to-ethane output ratio, a temperature of 850 ºC and an input feed ratio of 4 are deemed more suitable. For the 4 % Na2WO4 composition, the Mn state proves to be the most effective, especially when prioritizing high efficiency and selectivity. Operating at a temperature of 850 ºC with a methane-to-oxygen input feed ratio of 2 is deemed suitable for achieving these objectives. In instances where a high methane conversion percentage is crucial, an input feed ratio of 6 is recommended. Conversely, if the goal is to optimize the ethylene-to-ethane ratio, operating at a temperature of 850 ºC with a methane-to-oxygen input feed ratio of 2 is the preferred condition. The performance of Mn/Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts in oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) varies significantly with Na2WO4 concentration (4–6 wt%) due to complex interrelated factors. The Na2WO4 concentration affects surface chemistry and phase distribution, influencing the density and effectiveness of active sites. The study emphasizes the importance of Na2WO4 concentration to maximize catalytic performance. To ensure the effectiveness of the applied changes, the reaction was repeated three times, and the results confirmed that these changes were effective. A Summary of the Comparison with Max Selectivity: 4 % MnNaW > Mn-NaW > NaW-Mn 5 % NaW-Mn > MnNaW > Mn-NaW 6 % MnNaW > NaW-Mn > Mn-NaW A Summary of the Comparison with Max Yield: 4 % MnNaW > Mn-NaW > NaW-Mn 5 % NaW-Mn > Mn-NaW > MnNaW 6 % MnNaW > NaW-Mn > Mn-NaW A Summary of the Comparison with Max C2H4/C2H6: 4 % Mn-NaW > NaW-Mn > MnNaW 5 % MnNaW > Mn-NaW > NaW-Mn 6 % MnNaW > NaW-Mn > Mn-NaW 3.3 Proposed mechanism for catalytic OCM Previous studies on the catalytic OCM reaction mechanism [106,107] have indicated that the C−H bond dissociation energy of CH4 is 439.3 kJ/mol, underscoring the robust nature of methane's C−H bonds [105]. This high stability arises from its tetrahedral geometry (TD), wherein the sp3 central carbon is bonded to four hydrogen atoms. Consequently, the resulting HOMO−LUMO gap renders it challenging to either donate an electron from the LUMO or remove one from the HOMO to activate the molecule [3]. However, when the catalyst surface interacts with a CH4 molecule, its tetrahedral geometry can be perturbed. This perturbation leads to a decrease in the C−H bond order of CH4, resulting in the stretching (weakening) of the C−H bonds and causing a distortion of the tetrahedral geometry. Ultimately, this weakening can lead to the rupture of the weak C−H bond, generating a methyl radical. In the presence of a catalyst, the production of methyl radicals (CH3•) can be facilitated through heterolytic cleavage, necessitating electron transfer between activated oxygen species on the catalyst surface and the adsorbed methane molecule [83,100]. Hence, an electron acceptor catalyst (reducible, Lewis acid) is essential to facilitate the absorption of CH4, leading to the formation of CH3. In contrast, an electron donor (oxidizable, Lewis base) is necessary to activate the gas-phase O2 molecule on the catalyst surface. This interplay is crucial for driving the OCM reaction effectively. It has been consistently demonstrated that the OCM mechanism involves the recombination of CH3• gas radicals to form C2H6 [83,104,108]. One of the seminal and most renowned mechanisms proposed for the OCM was introduced by Lee et al. The Li mechanism, initially proposed for the Mn2O3/Na2WO4/SiO2 supported catalyst, gained widespread recognition following the studies by Li et al. [109] and later corroborated by Wang et al. [110] According to this mechanism, depicted in Fig. 11 below, two distinct active metal oxide sites synergistically operate. The activation of the CH4 molecule occurs via surface lattice oxygen associated with the surface WO4 site (W6+), resulting in the generation of a gaseous methyl radical and the reduction of the surface WOx site (W6+ → W5+). This process is accompanied by the transfer of electrons from W5+ to Mn3+, leading to the regeneration of the W site and the reduction of Mn3+ to Mn2+ and Mn3+. Subsequently, Mn2+ participates in the gas-phase activation of molecular O2, forming surface oxygen species through electron donation and generating an Mn site once again [111,112]. In the simultaneous addition method, Mn and Na2WO4 are co-deposited, leading to a balanced distribution of these active phases on the SiO2 surface. At 4 % Na2WO4, the concentration is sufficient to allow effective dispersion without leading to agglomeration or excessive surface coverage, which might occur at higher loadings. This balanced distribution ensures that both Mn and W species are accessible and well-integrated within the catalyst matrix, leading to a higher density of active sites. The co-deposition facilitates the formation of synergistic Mn-W interactions, where Mn can enhance the activation of methane by facilitating the formation of methyl radicals. Simultaneously, the presence of W in close proximity stabilizes these intermediates, promoting the coupling reactions that lead to the formation of C2+ hydrocarbons. This synergy is more pronounced at the 4 % Na2WO4 level, where the balance between Mn and W is optimized, avoiding the formation of inactive or less active phases that might occur at higher Na2WO4 loadings. The simultaneous deposition at 4 % Na2WO4 likely results in the formation of an optimal network of active sites where Mn and W are intimately mixed at the nanoscale. This close proximity allows for efficient charge transfer and interaction between the catalytic species, facilitating the OCM reaction. The resulting structure is more stable and less prone to deactivation compared to other modes of addition, where the phases might be less uniformly distributed. 4 Conclusion The primary objective of this study was to optimize the activity and selectivity of the Mn/Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst for the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) by refining the catalyst preparation method through incipient-wetness impregnation and systematically investigating the impact of various operating parameters. The research focused on understanding how different sequences and concentrations of Mn and Na2WO4 incorporation influence the catalyst’s performance in terms of selectivity, yield, and the C2H4/C2H6 ratio. Our findings demonstrate that the preparation method, particularly the sequence of Mn and Na2WO4 addition, plays a crucial role in determining the distribution of active sites and the interaction between the catalyst’s components. The Mn2O3 phase, known for its ability to enhance oxygen mobility, is significantly affected by how and when it is introduced in the catalyst synthesis process. This, in turn, influences the efficiency of methane activation and the subsequent formation of C2 hydrocarbons. The investigation into the three different preparation methods—MnNaW (simultaneous addition), Mn-NaW (Mn first, then NaW), and NaW-Mn (NaW first, then Mn)—revealed that the MnNaW catalyst, where Mn and Na2WO4 are added together, consistently outperformed the others in most metrics, particularly at Na2WO4 concentrations of 4 % and 6 %. This method resulted in a more uniform distribution of Mn2O3 and Na2WO4, optimizing the catalyst’s ability to selectively oxidize methane to C2 hydrocarbons while maintaining a high yield. Specifically, the MnNaW catalyst exhibited superior C2 selectivity, yield, and a favorable C2H4/C2H6 ratio under these conditions, indicating its suitability for efficient OCM processes. In contrast, the NaW-Mn preparation method showed the highest selectivity and yield at a 5 % Na2WO4 concentration. This suggests that introducing Na2WO4 first stabilizes the support, allowing for better dispersion and interaction of Mn2O3 when added later, enhancing the catalyst’s performance. The Mn-NaW method, although less effective overall, particularly excelled in maximizing the C2H4/C2H6 ratio at lower Na2WO4 concentrations, indicating that it may be more effective in promoting ethylene formation under certain conditions. In summary, the study concludes that the catalyst’s performance can be significantly optimized by carefully controlling the preparation method and operating parameters. The MnNaW catalyst, prepared via simultaneous impregnation, emerges as the most robust method for achieving high selectivity and yield in OCM, especially at Na2WO4 concentrations of 4 % and 6 %. These findings provide valuable insights for the development of more efficient OCM catalysts, emphasizing the critical role of preparation methods in optimizing catalytic activity and selectivity. Future research should continue to explore the intricate relationships between preparation techniques, catalyst structure, and performance to further enhance the efficiency of OCM processes. coredata.dc:description: This study presents various preparation methods for synthesizing a 2 %Mn-4 %Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst for the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) using an incipient-wetness impregnation procedure in one/two steps. The catalyst preparation involved modifying various additions and investigating the combination of 4 %, 5 %, and 6 % Na2WO4. Specifically, the effects of operating temperature and the methane-to-oxygen ratio on the catalyst's performance were investigated. The results suggest that the 2 %Mn-4 %Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst can operate efficiently under a low methane-to-oxygen feed ratio, making it suitable for OCM reactors. In our packed-bed quartz glass reactor, the dry-impregnated catalyst exhibited excellent performance, with a C2 selectivity of 37.20 %, ethylene selectivity of 13.94 %, ethane subselectivity of 23.26 %, and C2 yield of 28.22 %.
